(CiP.1621)The Cabinet were informed that the subjectof repatriation of the Austrian, Hungarian andether prisoners still in Siberia had engaged theattention of the Supreme Economic Council and of theCouncil of the League of Nations for some monthspast, and, at the request of the Council of theLeague, Pr Nansen had been investigating the problem.As a result, a scheme had been developed for the appropriation of the funds of the international committee on Relief Credits for purposes of repatriation. It was estimated that, includingshipping, a sum of about 850,000 would be required.All the borrowing nations were agreeable to thediverting of this sum to this purpose from the amount available for reconstruction; but the Eelief Committeehad not felt warranted in diverting the proposed- 1 - proposed sum without the specific sanction of the Governments which had provided the funds. In Dr Hanson's view, the matter was one of great urgency, as, unless relief were forth-coming before tho next winter, there would be an enormous mortality among the prisoners and wide-spread demoralisation among them and their relatives. The Governments of Norway, Holland, Switzerland and Denmark were in favour of granting assistance; Sweden was making grants through the Red Cross Society; France would probably follow the lead given by this country; while there was no liklihood of the United States co-operating. No fresh money from the Treasury was asked for.
The Cabinet were reminded of the question put in the House of Commons on the 28th June on the subject and the answers then given by the Prime Minister: that, if help were given, it would only be by this country in conjunction with other countries with whom we are associated.
The Cabinet agreed:
To ask the Chancellor of the Exchequer to authorise Sir John Bradbury to charge the British share of the sum required to the British Relief grant on condition that the other European Powers did their share to find the rest of the sum required. It was to be understood that no charge against the fund was to be admitted for the repatriation of German prisoners.

(3) The Cabinet were asked as a matter of urgency to consider the desirability of increasing the passenger fares on the railways in order to give effect to the Government policy of avoiding a subsidy. It was explained that the railway deficit on the year was estimated at £54,000,000, and, in order to remove this in 8 months, it would be necessary to levy £74,000.000 on goods and passenger traffic. The Minister of Transport had conferred with the Lord Privy Seal and the Chancellor of the Exchequer who were agreed that the deficit ought to be spread over a few months of the next financial year. The question of revising passenger rates was now before the Rates Advisory Committee and their Report would not be received at a date which would permit an increase of fares earlier than August 1st. But to raise the fares on the eve of the Bank Holiday would arouse great popular opposition: while, to delay even for a week, would involve a loss of about £1,000,000. A questions was down in the House that afternoon on the subject.
The Cabinet authorised the Minister of Transport to reply as follows:
"I would refer the Honourable Member to Cmd. paper 815 and to the replies given to a similar question by the Honourable member for South Molton on the 12th July. The Government is most desirous of causing as little inconvenience as possible consistently with the principle that the railways must be put upon what is estimated to be a self-supporting basis. It is not proposed to increase the charge for ordinary tickets before the 5th August, which will meet the case of the Bank Holiday traffic. bv/AIiCBS (4) Pith reference to Conclusion 5 of a Conference of3IKCLBUhifCBCOIEG hinisters held on July 5th IS20, the Cabinet hadITylKG who I)ihlffiK.'l:T "belore them a Loraorandum by the minister oi labourISTIV23.(0.1,1508), and a heaorandum by the Jiancollcr ofthe Ii;chenuer (C.x * 1508 -J , deilinp with ,. proposalto grant to a single man in training an allowance fora widowed mother dependent u on Mia and living athis home of 10/- nor week.
